Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Imaging Surveillance After Endovascular Aortic Repair

Background: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of imaging surveillance compliance on reintervention rates and mortality in patients undergoing endovascular aortic repair (EVAR).

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 11 retrospective cohort studies involving 21,838 patients were conducted. The studies compared compliant and partially/noncompliant patients with imaging surveillance protocols. The primary outcome was the reintervention rate, and the secondary outcome was all-cause mortality, measured over a median follow-up of 31.7 months. The review protocol was registered at PROSPERO (CRD42017080494).

Results: The overall reintervention rate was 5%, with a risk difference (RD) of 4% (95% CI 1% to 7%) favoring partial/noncompliance, implying a number needed to harm of 25 (95% CI 14 to 100). The overall mortality rate was 31%, with a nonsignificant RD of 12% (95% CI âˆ’2% to 26%) in favor of partial/noncompliance. Two studies reported that 41% to 53% of reinterventions were due to complications detected through imaging surveillance, while others were detected through patient symptoms.

Interpretation: Compliance with imaging surveillance after EVAR appears to lead to more reinterventions without reducing mortality, suggesting that yearly imaging may not be beneficial for all patients. The study highlights the need for a more tailored approach to post-EVAR surveillance.

Trial registration: PROSPERO CRD42017080494

Funding: Not specified.
